pullRequest.body:
- Define `WalkingReflexivePair`, the category indexing reflexive pair.
- Show that the forgetful functor from this category to `WalkingParallelPair` is `Final`.
- Show that coequalizers of reflexive pairs are equivalent to colimits of diagrams indexed by `WalkingReflexivePair`.
- Show that having coequalizers of all reflexive pairs is equivalent to having all `WalkingReflexivePair`-shaped colimits.

---

There are probably a few names that could be better, perhaps some statements would belong to a new `ReflexivePair` namespace?

I ended up changing the name of `forgetReflexion` to `inclusionWalkingReflexivePair` in the `WalkingParallelPair` namespace. It leads to rather long names but Iâ€™m out of ideas of a better name.
This PR needs some modifications so as to fit more into the mathlib conventions, but the results look very nice to me.

Thank you for the extensive review and the numerous tricks I did not know about!
I have implemented your suggestions, and added a few new constructors to bundles functors from or towards a term of the form `reflexivePair â€¦`.
To avoid cluttering things too much, I decided not to put a constructor for natural transforms between two `reflexivePair`, because it can already be constructed with `mkNatTrans` and `mkNatTrans'` if needed.

I renamed `inclusionWalkingReflexivePairEquivCocone` to `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork`, and `ofIsReflexivePairColimitEquiv` to `reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer`. Since weâ€™are adding simps lemmas, I took the liberty to also add `ofIsReflexivePair_map_left`, `ofIsReflexivePair_map_right`, `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_functor_obj_Ï€` and `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_inverse_obj_Ï€` for completeness. I couldnâ€™t golf more the proof of the latter unfortunately.
This has been rebased onto https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17723, on which it now depends on.

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11341532320/job/31539992679)

As this is available in mathlib, I would advocate for a definition of the category `WalkingReflexivePair` by using generators and relations as follows:

```lean
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.PathCategory

namespace CategoryTheory.Limits

inductive WalkingReflexivePairQuiver : Type where
  | zero
  | one

namespace WalkingReflexivePairQuiver

inductive Hom : WalkingReflexivePairQuiver â†’ WalkingReflexivePairQuiver â†’ Type
  | left : Hom zero one
  | right : Hom zero one
  | section_ : Hom one zero

instance : Quiver WalkingReflexivePairQuiver where
  Hom := Hom

abbrev left : zero âŸ¶ one := Hom.left
abbrev right : zero âŸ¶ one := Hom.right
abbrev section_ : one âŸ¶ zero := Hom.section_

inductive homRel : HomRel (Paths WalkingReflexivePairQuiver)
  | section_left : homRel (section_.toPath â‰« left.toPath) (ðŸ™ _)
  | section_right : homRel (section_.toPath â‰« right.toPath) (ðŸ™ _)

end WalkingReflexivePairQuiver

def WalkingReflexivePair := Quotient WalkingReflexivePairQuiver.homRel
  deriving Category

end CategoryTheory.Limits
```

It should make a few constructions slightly easier (removing case by case studies). Only the proof that the inclusion from `WalkingParallelPair` is final would need some changes.

(If it is too complicated to get the cofinality property, you may keep the more explicit approach.)

```
I do not know what is purpose of these ` â†‘`?

`â†‘` causes `simp` to apply the lemma after simplifying a subterm (I believe this is the default, so it shouldn't be necessary). You can also use `â†“` to cause `simp` to apply lemmas before simplifying a subterm.
It seems this is a particular case of `reflexivePair`, so that it is not necessary to reproduce the construction. You may apply `reflexivePair` to `f`, `g` and `commonSection f g`.

```suggestion
    | right_reflexion => g â‰« commonSection f g
    | left_reflexion => f â‰« commonSection f g
```

```suggestion
Authors: Bhavik Mehta, Robin Carlier
```

As these lemmas should not be needed outside of the definition of the category structure, I would suggest doing this:
```suggestion
instance walkingReflexivePairCategory : SmallCategory WalkingReflexivePair where
  Hom := WalkingReflexivePairHom
  id := id
  comp := comp
  comp_id f := by cases f <;> rfl
  id_comp f := by cases f <;> rfl
  assoc f g h := by cases f <;> cases g <;> cases h <;> rfl
```
All the definition related to the category `WalkingReflexivePair` should be in the same namespace, like `WalkingReflexivePair.Hom`, etc.

In Lean 4, the preferred syntax is:
```suggestion
def inclusionWalkingReflexivePair : WalkingParallelPair â¥¤ WalkingReflexivePair where
  obj := fun x => match x with
```

With the following attribute, the next few lemmas shall become unnecessary:
```suggestion
@[simps!]
def inclusionWalkingReflexivePair : WalkingParallelPair â¥¤ WalkingReflexivePair :=
```

`intro/rcases` can be combined as:
```suggestion
              rintro p hâ‚ hâ‚‚ âŸ¨l, y, fâŸ©
```
(There is another similar situation below.)

```suggestion
    StructuredArrow.mk (Y := WalkingParallelPair.zero) (ðŸ™ _)
```

```suggestion
    WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C where
```

When doing computation in category theory, it is advisable to do always rewrite `assoc` in the forward direction, and use `_assoc` versions of lemmas (created by the `reassoc` attribute) as well as `reassoc_of% ...` in the case of specific equalities:
```suggestion
  map_comp := by
    rintro _ _ _ âŸ¨âŸ© g <;> cases g <;>
      simp only [Category.id_comp, Category.comp_id, Category.assoc, sl, sr,
        reassoc_of% sl, reassoc_of% sr] <;> rfl
```

As much as possible, one the `Category` instance has been defined, we should use `â‰«` (`CategoryStruct.comp`) instead of the `comp` defined above. It would take the following form:
```lean
theorem walkingReflexivePairHom_left_comp_reflexion :
  (left â‰« reflexion : one âŸ¶ one) = left_reflexion := rfl```
```
(The annoying thing is that Lean cannot guess that `left` and `reflexion` are morphisms in a category, so that we need to help them a little bit.)
Actually, I am not convinced that this would be the best normal form, I would rather suggest keeping `left â‰« reflexion` as the normal form (and then `left_reflexion` is part of the internals of the implementation; by the way, `leftCompReflexion` may be a name that fits better our naming conventions!?)

However, the following lemmas would be useful:
```lean
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
theorem reflexion_comp_left : reflexion â‰« left = ðŸ™ zero := rfl

@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
theorem reflexion_comp_right : reflexion â‰« right = ðŸ™ zero := rfl
```
(With this combination of `reassoc` of `simp`, we should get reasonable normal forms for morphisms in that category.)

Using the `reflexion_comp_left` lemma suggested above: 
```suggestion
        F.map reflexion â‰« F.map left = ðŸ™ (F.obj zero) := by
  rw [â† F.map_comp, reflexion_comp_left, F.map_id]
```
(Note also the parentheses change.)

Doing the following, `F.map reflexion â‰« F.map left â‰«f` will simplify into `f`: 
```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr:= simp)]
```

With this, Lean will try to fill in the proofs automatically: 
```suggestion
def reflexivePair (f g : A âŸ¶ B) (s : B âŸ¶ A) (sl : s â‰« f = ðŸ™ B := by aesop_cat) (sr : s â‰« g = ðŸ™ B := by aesop_cat) :
```
Then, you should also add lemmas like
```lean
@[simp] lemma reflexivePair_obj_zero : (reflexivePair f g s sl sr).obj zero = B := rfl
```
and similarly `obj_one`, `map_left`, `map_right` and `map_reflexion`.

Taking into account suggestions above, I would proceed like this:
```lean
def diagramIsoReflexivePair (F : WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C) :
    F â‰… reflexivePair (F.map left) (F.map right) (F.map reflexion) :=
  NatIso.ofComponents (fun x â†¦ match x with
    | zero => Iso.refl _
    | one => Iso.refl _)
  (fun f â†¦ by cases f <;> simp)
```
(As much as possible, I feel it is slightly better not to use `eqToIso`.)
More generally, as you have defined a constructor for functors from the category `WalkingReflexivePair`, it would be nice to introduce also a constructor for natural transformations (and then natural isomorphisms) between objets in `WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C`. Then, `diagramIsoReflexivePair` would appear as a special case of this.
I would use `abbrev` instead of `def` here.

  | zero => exact âŸ¨StructuredArrow.mk (Y := one) (ðŸ™ _)âŸ©

instance (X : WalkingReflexivePair) :
    IsConnected (StructuredArrow X inclusionWalkingReflexivePair) := by
  cases X with
  | zero =>
      refine IsConnected.of_induct  (jâ‚€ := StructuredArrow.mk (Y := one) (ðŸ™ _)) ?_
      rintro p hâ‚ hâ‚‚ âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ©âŸ©, (_ | _), âŸ¨_âŸ©âŸ©
      Â· exact (hâ‚‚ (StructuredArrow.homMk .left)).2 hâ‚
      Â· exact hâ‚
  | one =>
      refine IsConnected.of_induct  (jâ‚€ := StructuredArrow.mk (Y := zero) (ðŸ™ _))
        (fun p hâ‚ hâ‚‚ â†¦ ?_)
      have hâ‚— : StructuredArrow.mk left âˆˆ p := (hâ‚‚ (StructuredArrow.homMk .left)).1 hâ‚
      have háµ£ : StructuredArrow.mk right âˆˆ p := (hâ‚‚ (StructuredArrow.homMk .right)).1 hâ‚
      rintro âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ¨âŸ©âŸ©, (_ | _), âŸ¨_âŸ©âŸ©

These lemmas should preferably be stated just after the definition of `reflexivePair`. The standard names should be `reflexivePair_obj_zero`, etc.

The following is slightly shorter:
```suggestion
  naturality _ _ f := by
    cases f
    all_goals
      dsimp
      simp only [Functor.map_id, Category.id_comp, Category.comp_id,
        Functor.map_comp, hâ‚, hâ‚‚, hâ‚ƒ, reassoc_of% hâ‚, reassoc_of% hâ‚‚,
        map_reflexion, map_left, map_right, Category.assoc]
```
Note that after `by`, it is usually recommended to do a line break with little indentation when the proof is not a one-liner.

variable {F : WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C}

This seems better to me for the next three definition. `varaiable (F)` should then be added after `mkNatIso`.

There are unnecessary parentheses.
(Also, I would make `f`, `g`, `s`, `sl`, `sr` implicit parameters here.)

Arguably, this would be slightly better:
```suggestion
@[simps!]
/-- Constructor for natural isomorphisms with a `reflexivePair`. -/
@[simps]
def mkNatIso (u : F.obj one â‰… A) (v : F.obj zero â‰… B)
    (hâ‚ : (F.map left) â‰« v.hom = u.hom â‰« f := by aesop_cat)
    (hâ‚‚ : (F.map right) â‰« v.hom = u.hom â‰« g := by aesop_cat)
    (hâ‚ƒ : (F.map reflexion) â‰« u.hom = v.hom â‰« s := by aesop_cat) :
    F â‰… reflexivePair f g s sl sr where
  hom := mkNatTrans u.hom v.hom 
  inv := mkNatTrans' u.inv v.inv
    (by rw [â† cancel_epi u.hom, u.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚, v.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
    (by rw [â† cancel_epi u.hom, u.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚‚, v.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
    (by rw [â† cancel_epi v.hom, v.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚ƒ, u.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
```

Actually, both `mkNatTrans` and `mkNatTrans'` are a special case of:
```lean
def mkNatTrans {F G : WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C}
    (eâ‚€ : F.obj zero âŸ¶ G.obj zero) (eâ‚ : F.obj one âŸ¶ G.obj one)
    (hâ‚ : F.map left â‰« eâ‚€ = eâ‚ â‰« G.map left := by aesop_cat)
    (hâ‚‚ : F.map right â‰« eâ‚€ = eâ‚ â‰« G.map right := by aesop_cat)
    (hâ‚ƒ : F.map reflexion â‰« eâ‚ = eâ‚€ â‰« G.map reflexion := by aesop_cat) :
    F âŸ¶ G where
  app := fun x â†¦ match x with
    | zero => eâ‚€
    | one => eâ‚
  naturality _ _ f := by
    cases f
    all_goals
      dsimp
      simp only [Functor.map_id, Category.id_comp, Category.comp_id,
        Functor.map_comp, hâ‚, hâ‚‚, hâ‚ƒ, reassoc_of% hâ‚, reassoc_of% hâ‚‚,
        map_reflexion, map_left, map_right, Category.assoc]
```
(It may be nice to produce (d)simp lemmas `mkNatTrans_app_zero` and `mkNatTrans_app_one`.)
Then, `mkNatIso` can be modified accordingly.
`variable {F G : WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C}` should be inserted before these declarations.

It would be better to use the same order of parameters as for `mkNatTrans`. (The proof could be exactly the same, or by constructing `hom`, and `inv` using `mkNatTrans` as I suggested.)
```suggestion
def mkNatIso (eâ‚€ : F.obj zero â‰… G.obj zero) (eâ‚ : F.obj one â‰… G.obj one)
```
(Same for `whiskerRightMkNatTrans`.)

```suggestion
    {hâ‚ƒ : F.map reflexion â‰« v = u â‰« G.map reflexion} (H : C â¥¤ D) :
    (whiskerRight (mkNatTrans u v : F âŸ¶ G) H) =
      mkNatTrans (H.map u) (H.map v)
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚])
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚‚])
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚ƒ]) := by
```

For readibility, it is advisable to announce the type of defs/abbrevs:
```suggestion
abbrev Ï€ (G : ReflexiveCofork F) : F.obj zero âŸ¶ G.pt := G.Î¹.app zero
```

It would be nice to add a constructor for `ReflexiveCofork`:
```lean
@[simps pt]
def mk {X : C} (Ï€ : F.obj zero âŸ¶ X) (h : F.map left â‰« Ï€ = F.map right â‰« Ï€) :
    ReflexiveCofork F where
  pt := X
  Î¹ := reflexivePair.mkNatTrans Ï€ (F.map left â‰« Ï€)

@[simp]
lemma mk_Ï€ {X : C} (Ï€ : F.obj zero âŸ¶ X) (h : F.map left â‰« Ï€ = F.map right â‰« Ï€) :
    (mk Ï€ h).Ï€ = Ï€ := rfl
```

`reassoc` is relevant only when the LHS (or the RHS) is a composition of morphisms. Same below.
```suggestion
@[simp]
```

```suggestion
    whiskerRight (mkNatTrans eâ‚€ eâ‚ : F âŸ¶ G) H =
      mkNatTrans (H.map eâ‚€) (H.map eâ‚)
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚])
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚‚])
          (by simp only [Functor.comp_obj, Functor.comp_map, â† Functor.map_comp, hâ‚ƒ]) := by
```

Linebreaks should be after infix operators:
```suggestion
  Cocones.precompose (diagramIsoParallelPair (_ â‹™ F)).symm.hom |>.obj <|
    G.whisker WalkingParallelPair.inclusionWalkingReflexivePair
```
(Same below.)
Got it, I thought the `<|` and `|>` were following the rules for parentheses rather than operators. Iâ€™ll try to be careful next time.

```suggestion
/-- A constructor for natural transformations between functors from `WalkingReflexivePair`. -/
```
The variables for this lemma and the next are the same as above, so that you should put these three definitions/lemmas in a `section` and use `variable ...`.

Is there a syntax to make the autoparam `:= by aesop_cat` apply to only the definition `mkNatTrans` while putting these variables in a `variable ...`? Or should I just leave the autoparam even for the lemmas?

I would favour a more down to earth definition here:
```suggestion
abbrev toCofork (G : ReflexiveCofork F) : Cofork (F.map left) (F.map right) :=
  Cofork.ofÏ€ G.Ï€ (by simp)
```

Then, `inclusionWalkingReflexivePairEquiv_obj` below would become an iso (use `Cofork.ext`) instead of an equality, and the definition of `ReflectiveCofork.isColimitEquiv` would have to be changed, using the composition with `IsColimit.equivIsoColimit (inclusionWalkingReflexivePairEquivObjIso G).symm)`.

```suggestion
  have := Limits.hasColimitOfIso <| inclusionWalkingReflexivePairOfIsReflexivePairIso f g
  apply Functor.Final.hasColimit_of_comp WalkingParallelPair.inclusionWalkingReflexivePair
```

A slightly better syntax (so that to avoid `@`, and arguably `have` is better than `suffices`):
```suggestion
  have := Limits.hasColimitOfIso (show _ â‰… parallelPair (F.map left) (F.map right) from
    diagramIsoParallelPair (WalkingParallelPair.inclusionWalkingReflexivePair â‹™ F))
  apply Functor.Final.hasColimit_of_comp WalkingParallelPair.inclusionWalkingReflexivePair
```

```suggestion
    [HasCoequalizer (F.map left) (F.map right)] : HasColimit F := by
```

I would declare `F` as an explicit variable here:
```suggestion
variable (F : WalkingReflexivePair â¥¤ C)
```

The following lemma could be useful:
```
lemma hasReflexiveCoequalizer_iff_hasCoequalizer :
    HasColimit F â†” HasCoequalizer (F.map left) (F.map right) := by
  simpa only [hasColimit_iff_hasInitial_cocone]
    using Equivalence.hasInitial_iff (inclusionWalkingReflexivePairEquivCocone F)
```

It is probably better to rely on the `ReflexiveCofork.isColimitEquiv` (which should be moved upwards):
```suggestion
noncomputable def reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer
    [HasCoequalizer (F.map left) (F.map right)] :
    colimit F â‰… coequalizer (F.map left) (F.map right) :=
  ((ReflexiveCofork.isColimitEquiv _).symm (colimit.isColimit F)).coconePointUniqueUpToIso
    (colimit.isColimit _)
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨fun _ â†¦ âŸ¨fun _ _ f g _ â†¦ (hasReflexiveCoequalizer_iff_hasCoequalizer
      (reflexivePair f g (commonSection f g))).1 inferInstanceâŸ©,
    fun _ â†¦ âŸ¨inferInstanceâŸ©âŸ©
```

```suggestion
/-- A constructor for natural transformations between functors from `WalkingReflexivePair`. -/
```

The name should have been `toCofork_Ï€`, but `Cofork.ofÏ€` behaves better as an abbrev, which makes the lemma unnecessary:
```suggestion
```
Here, we need a specific docstring saying this is an isomorphism.

The point of my suggested lemma `hasReflexiveCoequalizer_iff_hasCoequalizer` was to facilitate the proofs of `reflexivePair_hasColimit_of_hasCoequalizer` and `ofIsReflexivePairHasColimit_of_hasCoequalizer`.

```suggestion
    (colimit.isColimit _)
    
variable {A B : C} {f g : A âŸ¶ B} [IsReflexivePair f g]
```

The name should contain `Iso`:
```suggestion
def reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer
```

You should also add two simp lemmas expressing compatibilities of this isomorphism with the canonical maps to the colimit and to the coequalizer. Names would be `Î¹_reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer_hom` and `Ï€_reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer_inv`. (Same remarls for `ofIsReflexivePairColimitEquiv` below.)

`HasColimit` is a `Prop`, then this instance is a "lemma" (not a "def"), so that according to our naming conventions we should use `_` to connect the different elements in the name:
```suggestion
instance ofIsReflexivePair_hasColimit_of_hasCoequalizer [HasCoequalizer f g] :
```
The name should be changed. For the "proof", it would be better to apply `reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer` to `ofIsReflexivePair f g` instead of proving it again.

```suggestion
  hom := mkNatTrans eâ‚€.hom eâ‚.hom
  inv := mkNatTrans eâ‚€.inv eâ‚.inv
        (by rw [â† cancel_epi eâ‚.hom, eâ‚.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚, eâ‚€.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
        (by rw [â† cancel_epi eâ‚.hom, eâ‚.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚‚, eâ‚€.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
        (by rw [â† cancel_epi eâ‚€.hom, eâ‚€.hom_inv_id_assoc, â† reassoc_of% hâ‚ƒ, eâ‚.hom_inv_id,
            Category.comp_id])
  hom_inv_id := by ext x; cases x <;> simp
  inv_hom_id := by ext x; cases x <;> simp
```

```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
```

```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
```

```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
```

```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
```

```suggestion
lemma reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_inverse_obj_Ï€
```
I will try to see if there is a better proof...

Could you add the following lemma in `Functor.Final`:
```lean
/-- Alternative equational lemma for `(extendCocone c).Î¹.app` in case a lift of the object
is given explicitly. -/
lemma extendCocone_obj_Î¹_app' (c : Cocone (F â‹™ G)) {X : D} {Y : C} (f : X âŸ¶ F.obj Y) :
    (extendCocone.obj c).Î¹.app X = G.map f â‰« c.Î¹.app Y := by
  sorry
```
and then the proof here can be:
```lean
@[simp]
lemma reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_inverse_obj_Ï€
    (G : Cofork (F.map left) (F.map right)) :
    ((reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork F).inverse.obj G).Ï€ = G.Ï€ := by
  dsimp only [reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork, Equivalence.symm, Equivalence.trans,
    ReflexiveCofork.Ï€, Cocones.precomposeEquivalence, Cocones.precompose,
    Functor.comp, Functor.Final.coconesEquiv]
  rw [Functor.Final.extendCocone_obj_Î¹_app' (Y := .one) (f := ðŸ™ zero)]
  simp
```
Thanks! I will add this lemma in a separate PR to avoid changing too much things in this one, and will apply this once this is merged.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory/Limits/Shapes/Reflexive): the walking reflexive pair

nodes.body:
As this is available in mathlib, I would advocate for a definition of the category `WalkingReflexivePair` by using generators and relations as follows:

```lean
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.PathCategory

namespace CategoryTheory.Limits

inductive WalkingReflexivePairQuiver : Type where
  | zero
  | one

namespace WalkingReflexivePairQuiver

inductive Hom : WalkingReflexivePairQuiver â†’ WalkingReflexivePairQuiver â†’ Type
  | left : Hom zero one
  | right : Hom zero one
  | section_ : Hom one zero

instance : Quiver WalkingReflexivePairQuiver where
  Hom := Hom

abbrev left : zero âŸ¶ one := Hom.left
abbrev right : zero âŸ¶ one := Hom.right
abbrev section_ : one âŸ¶ zero := Hom.section_

inductive homRel : HomRel (Paths WalkingReflexivePairQuiver)
  | section_left : homRel (section_.toPath â‰« left.toPath) (ðŸ™ _)
  | section_right : homRel (section_.toPath â‰« right.toPath) (ðŸ™ _)

end WalkingReflexivePairQuiver

def WalkingReflexivePair := Quotient WalkingReflexivePairQuiver.homRel
  deriving Category

end CategoryTheory.Limits
```

It should make a few constructions slightly easier (removing case by case studies). Only the proof that the inclusion from `WalkingParallelPair` is final would need some changes.

(If it is too complicated to get the cofinality property, you may keep the more explicit approach.)

@robin-carlier This PR looks mostly fine, but there are still some places where it needs some work. I see that you have attempted to process some of the review comments. Are you planning to continue working on this PR? Would you like some help from others, or do you want to hand over completely?

> @robin-carlier This PR looks mostly fine, but there are still some places where it needs some work. I see that you have attempted to process some of the review comments. Are you planning to continue working on this PR? Would you like some help from others, or do you want to hand over completely?

I am taking a break from math (and consequently lean)-related stuff for the time being, so I donâ€™t plan to start working back on this in the near future and Iâ€™d gladly hand it over completely if someone wants to work on this or if this content is needed.

</details>
I ended up changing the name of `forgetReflexion` to `inclusionWalkingReflexivePair` in the `WalkingParallelPair` namespace. It leads to rather long names but Iâ€™m out of ideas of a better name.
This PR needs some modifications so as to fit more into the mathlib conventions, but the results look very nice to me.

Thank you for the extensive review and the numerous tricks I did not know about!
I have implemented your suggestions, and added a few new constructors to bundles functors from or towards a term of the form `reflexivePair â€¦`.
To avoid cluttering things too much, I decided not to put a constructor for natural transforms between two `reflexivePair`, because it can already be constructed with `mkNatTrans` and `mkNatTrans'` if needed.

I renamed `inclusionWalkingReflexivePairEquivCocone` to `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork`, and `ofIsReflexivePairColimitEquiv` to `reflexiveCoequalizerIsoCoequalizer`. Since weâ€™are adding simps lemmas, I took the liberty to also add `ofIsReflexivePair_map_left`, `ofIsReflexivePair_map_right`, `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_functor_obj_Ï€` and `reflexiveCoforkEquivCofork_inverse_obj_Ï€` for completeness. I couldnâ€™t golf more the proof of the latter unfortunately.
